position.marginalia_text: Glareanì, et Velcurionis schola[e] Liuiana[e]: saltem post singulorum librorum lectionem, sigillatim percurrenda[e]: ne quid fortè pra[e]termittatur, pra[e]cipua obseruatione dignum. Hîc enim qua[e]dam pra[e]gnantia, et exquisita: pla[e]raq[ue] alicuius nota[e]. Velcurìo ferè talis Politicus, pra[e]sertim in Catalogis Legum, atq[ue] Morum; qualis Italicè Machiauellus in suis Liuianis Obseruationibus; inscriptis, Discorsi sopra la prima deca di T. Liuio. In vtroq[ue] egregia fundamenta tam Disciplina[e], quàm Jurisprudentia[e] Romana[e]: nec quicq[uam] fermè, aut industrio viro dignius, aut politico: pra[e]sertim post Aristotelis Principia Politica; vndè omnes egregiae Hypotheses politica[e], in quovis Regnorum, aut Rerumpublicarum statu. Prudentis interest, ea peritè, profundeq[ue] seligere, qua[e] sunt suo Statui aptissima; nec tam acutissimum philosophum agere, quàm reuerâ vtilissimum politicum. Id et olim ciuis Romani erat; et hodiè est subiecti Britannici. Nihil excellens pra[e]termittendum: sed pra[e]cipuè Legum, Armorumq[ue] Mnemosyna, curioso, solidoq[ue] iudicio obseruanda: et siquid posset nostra[e] Reipublica[e] conducere, id est in primis perpendendum.

book.title: In omneis Titi Livii decadas annotationes

marginalia.translation: The Livian expositions of Glareanus and Velcurio should be skimmed one by one, at least after reading each one of the individual books, in case one accidentally missed out on something worthy of particular notice. For some things here are rich in meaning and precise; and most are of at least some significance. Velcurio was just such a politician, especially in his catalogue of laws and customs, as Macchiavelli was in his commentary on Livy, entitled 'Discorsi sopra la prima deca di T. Livio'. In each of these one finds outstanding foundations of both Roman discipline and jurisprudence; and hardly anything is more worthwhile for an active man, or politician, especially after Aristotle's Political Principles. On these are based all excellent political case studies of any form of kingdoms or republics. It is important for the prudent man to choose expertly and meticulously which ones are most suitable for his form, and to act not so much as a very sharp philosopher but in fact rather as an extremely useful politician. This was once also important for the Roman citizen, and it is today for the British subject. One must not skip any superb matter, but observe especially with a careful and firm judgment the track records of laws and military actions. And anything that could be beneficial for our state should be examined above all.

position.marginalia_text: Trìa Optìma Maxìma Romanorum biblia, Plinius, Liuius, Plutarchus: Plinius ad cognitionem: Liuius ad actionem: Plutarchus ad Vtramq[ue]. Summa summarum, Ca[e]sar: tam prudentissimi consilij, quàm fortissima[e] actionis Auctor singularis; et omnino excellentissimus magister militaris Artis, et Virtutìs, id est, Victoria[e], ipsiusq[ue] Fortuna[e]. Politici interest, Ca[e]sari adiungere Tacitum: qui perinde est Pragmaticorum solertissimus, vt Ca[e]sar bellatorum valìdissimus: vterq[ue] pernecessarius tam profundo consiliario, quàm strenuo Ducì. Adde Heroica[e] Virtutis, diuiniq[ue] Zeli miracula: nihil supra.

marginalia.translation: The three most superior books of the Romans are: Pliny, Livy, and Plutarch. Pliny for knowledge, Livy for action, Plutarch for both. Caesar is the ultimate top: an extraordinary author of equally the most prudent counsel and the bravest action, as well as an absolutely superior master of military skill and virtue, in other words: of victory and fortune itself. It is useful for the politician to add Tacitus to Caesar, who is the most expert of pragmatics in the same manner as Caesar is the most powerful of warriors. Both are absolutely essential for a thorough counsellor as well as an energetic leader. Add to this the miracles of heroic virtue and divine zeal: there is nothing superior to that.

position.marginalia_text: Nullus historicorum tantum habet ciuilis iurisconsulti, aut forensis pragmatici, quàm Liuius, et post eum Tacitus, callidusq[ue] Frontinus. Nouissimè etiam Guicciardinus, Zuingerus, Chytraeus, alij perpauci nonnihil habent pragmatici. Hodiè multi asini ausi sunt componere historias, chronica, annales, commentarios: vt ferè Graftonus, Stous, Holinshedus, non pauci tales: nec iureconsulti, nec politici, nec ethologi, nec vllo modo eruditi. Liuium Britannicum quàm diu desiderabimus? Ah quando exstabit Tacitus, Frontinusue Britannicus? Nugis affluimus: pragmaticaru[m], bellicarumue rerum quàm ieiuna memoria? Solus ferè Morus, et Aschamus nonnihil attigerunt pristina[e] artis, et industria[e]. Tandem etiam Cambdenus, Hacluitus, [....]

marginalia.translation: No historian has so much of the civil lawyer or legal practitioner as Livy, and after him, Tacitus and the shrewd Frontinus. Since very recently also Guicciardini, Zwinger, Chytraeus, and very few others have some features of the pragmatic. Nowadays many asses have dared to write histories, chronicles, annals and commentaries, such as Grafton, Stous, Holinshed, and not a few others of this kind. They are neither jurists, nor politicians, nor experts in character, nor learned in any way whatsoever. How long will we be missing a British Livy? Ah, when will there be a British Tacitus or Frontinus? We abound in worthless works, but how poor is our record of pragmatic and military affairs! Only More, almost, and Ascham took up some amount of the old art and activity. Finally also Cambden, Hakluyt, [. . .]

underline.text: futiles autem & nullius penè momenti, reiecimus
